Note: This course is scheduled in teaching periods that occur between orientation week and week 5 in Terms 1 and 3.


This course focuses on the ‘lawyering’ skills essential to legal practice. The course covers the relevant competencies for lawyer’s skills, problem solving, work management and business skills, prescribed by the Legal Profession Uniform Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers).  


It includes a 5-day compulsory onsite at the start of the course with workshops on advocacy, dispute resolution, negotiation, interviewing, legal drafting, letter writing, problem solving, and oral communication skills. This course provides the students with opportunities to build on and consolidate the lawyering skills acquired during the LLB/JD or equivalent in the context of acting for clients across different areas of legal practice.


This course is a mandatory course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). You must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course.

This assessment item is an introduction to all competencies.

Students can only receive a result of Not Yet Competent (CN) or Competent (CO) as determined by attendance and observation of the onsite facilitators and mentors.

N.B. At least a competent level must be obtained on all assessment tasks in order to be considered competent for the course (i.e. an NYC is not acceptable against any item).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2553f28cdb1a3050595850d8f496199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2553f28cdb1a3050595850d8f496199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2953f28cdb1a3050595850d8f4961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2d53f28cdb1a3050595850d8f496199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3153f28cdb1a3050595850d8f49619ac","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Letter Writing","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment item is a capstone of the competencies with a focus on re-writing a letter of advice to meet the needs of a client.  

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2553f28cdb1a3050595850d8f496199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2553f28cdb1a3050595850d8f496199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2953f28cdb1a3050595850d8f4961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ad53f28cdb1a3050595850d8f49619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practiques","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Satisfactory completion of all practiques and RAW Mind Coach modules in accordance with the relevant practical legal training competency standards. Eighteen Competencies are covered over 10 practiques (Lawyer’s Skills – 8, Problem Solving – 4, Work Management and Business Skills – 6).  

Students can only receive a result of Not Yet Competent (CN) or Competent (CO) for this assessment. To receive a CO result, all practiques must be completed.

This assessment item is a capstone of the competencies with a focus on re-drafting another legal document to meet the needs of the client.   

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

Note: This course is scheduled in teaching periods that occur between orientation week and week 5 in terms 1 and 3.


This course focuses on the ethical values and professional responsibility obligations of lawyers, including the skills and knowledge required to properly maintain trust and general account records in legal practice. Online Quizzes

Online learning modules will support the Professional Responsibility competency.

Students will be required to complete and pass an online quiz for each module in order to progress through and complete the online Professional Responsibility modules.

This approach will scaffold the learning required to complete the Professional Responsibility components of the coursework in the Skills in Practice, Litigation Practice, Transactional Practice, and Additional Practice Areas courses.

Note: This course is scheduled in teaching periods that occur between week 6 and week 10 in terms 1 and 3.


This course focuses on the lawyer’s role in the management and resolution of civil disputes. It covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for civil litigation practice prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


This course provides the opportunity to build on, consolidate and apply your knowledge and understanding of substantive law and court processes attained during your law degree to complete tasks and activities that reflect the work lawyers undertake in conducting civil litigation matters in legal practice. It will use and further develop your writing, drafting, legal research, analytical and problem-solving skills, in the context of representing a client throughout the different stages of a civil dispute matter – from the initial stage of assessing and advising on the merits of a client’s case to taking steps to enforce court orders and settlement agreements. 


This course is a mandatory course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and complete the compulsory 5-day onsite component of the Skills in Practice course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"11357240db5a3050595850d8f4961990","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Client file: Drafting Response to Interlocutory Application and Oral Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment item covers competencies 4 and 5. Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  1. prepare written submission opposing defendant’s application to set aside default judgment;
  2. draft answering affidavit;
  3. Record or attend a web conference to make the oral submission; and
  4. Reflect on their oral submission for the Loop Project.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"51357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"55357240db5a3050595850d8f4961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961994","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Client file: Drafting terms of settlement, examination notice and memo regarding enforcement steps","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment item covers competencies 6 and 7. Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  1. draft part terms of settlement (obligations plus enforcement clause for non-compliance);
  2. draft an examination notice; and
  3. prepare a memorandum outlining and ranking recommended enforcement steps.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"51357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21357240db5a3050595850d8f49619a9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practiques","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Satisfactory completion of all practiques in accordance with the relevant practical legal training competency standards. Competencies 1 to 7 are covered over 7 practiques.

Students can only receive a result of Not Yet Competent (CN) or Competent (CO) for this assessment. To receive a CO result, all practiques must be completed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"51357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69357240db5a3050595850d8f49619ad","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Client file: Letter of Advice and Statement of Claim","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment item covers competencies 1, 2 and 3. Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to draft:

  1. letter of advice to client; and
  2. a statement of claim

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

N.B. At least a competent level must be obtained on all assessment tasks in order to be considered competent for the course (i.e. an NYC is not acceptable against any item).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"51357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5d357240db5a3050595850d8f4961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a1357240db5a3050595850d8f49619b2","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PLTX1060.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Note: This course is scheduled in teaching periods that occur across the exam period and term break in terms 1 and 3.


This course focuses on the transactions commonly dealt with by lawyers practising in the areas of property practice, and commercial and corporate practice. It covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for those practice areas prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


This course builds on and consolidates students' knowledge of property law, company law and commercial law attained during your law degree to complete tasks and activities that reflect the transactions that lawyers commonly undertake in these areas of practice. It will use and further develop students' writing, drafting, legal research, analytical and problem-solving skills, in the context of representing a client in transactions such as the sale and purchase of land, a lease, and the sale or purchase of a business (including the financing of those transactions). 


This course is a mandatory course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and complete the compulsory 5-day onsite component of the Skills in Practice course.

This assessment item covers competencies CCP1, CCP3, CCP4 and PROP2.

Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  • Write a letter of advice on the commercial transaction
  • Draft special condition(s) to the contract; and
  • Complete a reflection on an ethical issue (for the Loop Project).

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

Administrative Law Practice focuses on government decision making.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Administrative Law Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes obtaining information under freedom of information legislation, obtaining the review of administrative decisions, and representing a client before courts and administrative tribunals.


This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

This assessment item covers competencies ADMIN 2 and 3.

Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  • Prepare for an oral submission in relation to the client file, including and accompanying written material required;
  • Record or attend a web conference to make an oral submission; and
  • Reflect on their oral submission for the Loop Project.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

contentlets.description:
Administrative Law Practice focuses on government decision making.

The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Administrative Law Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 

Course content includes obtaining information under freedom of information legislation, obtaining the review of administrative decisions, and representing a client before courts and administrative tribunals.

This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

Banking and Finance focuses on the financing of commercial transactions and drafting simple loan agreements and associated security documents.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Banking and Finance Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes preliminary investigation for a borrower’s proposal, planning transactions and agreements, drafting documents and ensuring legal requirements are met, undertaking due diligence, advising clients, and finalising documentation according to law.


This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

Criminal Law Practice focuses on the practices and procedures involved in acting for clients in criminal law matters.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Criminal Law Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes providing advice to clients, applying for bail, making pleas on behalf of clients, representing a client in minor matters, and assisting to prepare cases for trial.

This assessment item covers competencies CRIM 1-3. Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  1. Advise the client; and
  2. Draft the appropriate accompanying documents.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f22f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fe2f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fe2f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0b2f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619dd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practiques","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Satisfactory completion of all practiques in accordance with the relevant practical legal training competency standards. Competencies CRIM1-5.

Students can only receive a result of Not Yet Competent (CN) or Competent (CO) for this assessment. To receive a CO result, all practiques must be completed.

N.B. At least a competent level must be obtained on all assessment tasks in order to be considered competent for the course (i.e. an NYC is not acceptable against any item).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f22f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fe2f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fe2f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"432f2608db1a3050595850d8f49619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Client file - Oral Submissions, accompanying written preparation and Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment item covers competencies CRIM 4-5. Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  1. Prepare for an oral submission in relation to the client file, including drafting the required accompanying written material;
  2. Record or attend a web conference to make an oral submission; and
  3. Complete a reflection for the Loop Project.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

Family Law Practice focuses on family relationship issues and disputes, including parenting and property issues.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Family Law Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes advising on and representing a client in matters relating to children and property, identifying appropriate dispute-resolution processes, and advising clients on pre-action procedures.


This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

Consumer Law Practice focuses on consumers’ rights and guarantees.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Consumer Law Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes obtaining information about a consumer protection complaint and identifying relevant legislation, drafting documents, initiating and responding to claims in accordance with rules and procedures, representing a client at a hearing, and taking action to implement outcomes.


This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

This assessment item covers competencies CON 3, 4 and 5.

Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  • Prepare for an oral submission in relation to the client file, including and accompanying written material required;
  • Record or attend a web conference to make an oral submission; and
  • Reflect on their oral submission for the Loop Project.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

N.B. At least a competent level must be obtained on all assessment tasks in order to be considered competent for the course (i.e. CN – Not Yet Competent – is not acceptable against any item).

contentlets.description:
Consumer Law Practice focuses on consumers’ rights and guarantees.

The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Consumer Law Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 

Course content includes obtaining information about a consumer protection complaint and identifying relevant legislation, drafting documents, initiating and responding to claims in accordance with rules and procedures, representing a client at a hearing, and taking action to implement outcomes.

This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

Employment and Industrial Relations Practice focuses on legal issues pertaining to employers and employees.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Employment and Industrial Relations Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes assessing merits and weaknesses of an employment law dispute, identifying dispute resolution alternatives, advising a client on procedures, commencing negotiations, initiating and responding to claims, representing the client, and taking action to implement outcomes.


This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

contentlets.description:
Employment and Industrial Relations Practice focuses on legal issues pertaining to employers and employees.

The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Employment and Industrial Relations Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 

Course content includes assessing merits and weaknesses of an employment law dispute, identifying dispute resolution alternatives, advising a client on procedures, commencing negotiations, initiating and responding to claims, representing the client, and taking action to implement outcomes.

This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.
contentlets.title: Employment and Industrial Relations Practice

Planning and Environmental Law Practice focuses on the law relevant to applications for the development and use of land.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Planning and Environmental Law Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes assessing the merits of a matter and advising a client, preparing planning applications or objections, initiating or responding to environmental claims, representing a client in resolving a planning matter or environmental claim, and implementing outcomes.


This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"94a79703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a9619ad","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Client File: Written Advice and Drafting","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment item covers competencies PEL 1, 2 & 3.

Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to draft:

  • An advice to a client; and
  • the appropriate accompanying documents.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor. 

N.B. At least a competent level must be obtained on all assessment tasks in order to be considered competent for the course (i.e. CN - Not Yet Competent - is not acceptable against any item).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"90a79703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ca79703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ca79703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5ca7d703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practiques","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Satisfactory completion of all practiques in accordance with the relevant practical legal training competency standards. Competencies PEL 1 - 5.

Students can only receive a result of Not Yet Competent (CN) or Competent (CO) for this assessment. To receive a CO result, all practiques must be completed.

N.B. At least a competent level must be obtained on all assessment tasks in order to be considered competent for the course (i.e. CN - Not Yet Competent - is not acceptable against any item).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"90a79703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ca79703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ca79703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"60a7d703dbf69c10eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Client File: Oral submissions and accompanying written preparation and Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment item covers competencies PEL 3, 4 and 5.

Students will receive a partner memo requesting them to:

  • Prepare for an oral submission in relation to the client file, including and accompanying written material required;
  • Record or attend a web conference to make an oral submission; and
  • Reflect on their oral submission for the Loop Project.

Students may receive results of Not Yet Competent (CN), Competent (CO) or Competent with Merit (CM) as graded by mentor.

Wills and Estates Practice focuses on the law relevant to drafting wills and administering deceased estates.


The course covers the relevant skills, values and competencies for the optional practice area of Wills and Estates Practice as prescribed by the Legal Profession Admission Rules 2015, Schedule 2 (Practical legal training competencies for entry-level lawyers). 


Course content includes preparing wills using appropriate forms and precedents, administering deceased estates including grant of probate applications, identifying debts and assets, and taking action to resolve wills and estates problems.


This course is an elective course for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP). Students must be enrolled in the GDLPP to enrol in this course and must have completed PLTX1020 Skills in Practice.

contentlets.description:
This workplace experience is a mandatory requirement for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice.  It involves undertaking approved workplace experience totalling 20 days and in accordance with the Legal Profession Admission Board accreditation requirements.

This workplace experience must be undertaken in Australia and is to be accumulated by undertaking no less than 2 full days of workplace experience per week or 4 x 4-hour sessions of workplace experience per week. Please note that 15 of the 20 days of workplace experience must be undertaken according to these requirements. It is permissible to apply for up to 5 of the remaining days credit for workplace experience accrued up to 2 years prior to starting PLT coursework.

This workplace experience will generally be undertaken after students have completed all required coursework for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice (GDLPP).  It provides the opportunity to apply the learning acquired during that coursework in a legal practice environment and under the supervision of an experienced legal practitioner.

An additional 20 days’ workplace experience to further enhance and consolidate students' workplace learning and understanding of law in practice.


Experience in a legal or law-related workplace that allows students to gain an understanding of the work that legal practitioners do in the course of legal practice. It encompasses work in a variety of legal environments and may include (in addition to work for a legal practitioner in private legal practice) work in a community legal centre, Legal Aid, a government legal department, legal department of a company, working as a Judge’s associate, or with a Tribunal member. It also includes appropriate experience gained in the 2-year period prior to commencement of the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice. 


The Workplace Experience 2 course is additional to the compulsory coursework and the 20 days' mandatory workplace experience undertaken for Workplace Experience 1 for the Graduate Diploma in Legal Professional Practice. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b9b2f24cdb1a3050595850d8f49619f7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Declarations","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The student must submit signed student and supervisor declarations from each workplace experience placement site for each period of workplace experience.

The sum of the days for all workplace experience placements in this course must not be less than 20 days.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79b2f24cdb1a3050595850d8f49619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"35b2364cdb1a3050595850d8f49619af","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Structured Reflective Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The student must submit a structured reflection piece in a form approved by UNSW Law.

The structured reflection piece will focus on the student's workplace experience placement.

Elements of the structured reflection include:

  • Experience-based learning
  • Incidental and informal learning
  • Self-directed learning
  • Formal organisational learning
  • Ways in which the student's capacities for practice were expanded
  • Professional socialisation, and
  • Workplace collaborations together with interpersonal and contextual factors.

The student can choose to submit polished file work from task-based and performance-based submissions produced during the GDLPP online coursework component and during the practicum component in support of reflective analysis.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[{"dependent_type":{"label":null,"value":null},"ai_cl_id":{"value":"PLTX2040","cl_id":"d1943200db5a3050595850d8f49619da","key":"code"},"association_type":{"label":"Exclusions","value":"10"},"association_desc":"","associated_ai_cl_id":{"value":"PLTX2020","cl_id":"938edd33db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961946","key":"code"},"cl_id":"35b2f24cdb1a3050595850d8f49619f4","assoc_credit_points":"6","assoc_active":"true","assoc_title":"Workplace Experience 2","assoc_cl_id":"35b2f24cdb1a3050595850d8f49619f4","assoc_short_title":"PLTX2020 - Workplace Experience 2","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2021/PLTX2020","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"PLTX2020","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Law and Justice","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"PLTX2040 - Practicum","description":"

An innovative alternative to Workplace Experience 2, the Practicum provides students with exciting opportunities to contribute to the design and implementation of a personal or professional project that reflects their interests.


The Practicum involves areas of innovation and technology, adaptive lawyering, or specialised social justice, through a combination of placement; simulated workplaces; technical learning spaces; law-related projects; continuing legal education; and structured reflective practice. The Practicum may involve acquiring additional specialised experience, skills, and knowledge with the guidance of UNSW. PLT and students are responsible for contributing to the design of their Practicum, in consultation with UNSW PLT.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9d943200db5a3050595850d8f49619dc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Declarations","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

If work placement is part of the individual Practicum experience, the student must submit a signed student and supervisor declaration, including brief explanation of the type of work undertaken. Declarations must be completed for each workplace experience placement undertaken as part of the Practicum Component.

The sum of the notional learning hours for all Practicum components in this course must be equivalent to 6 Units of Credit (approximately 150 hours).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d5943200db5a3050595850d8f49619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9943200db5a3050595850d8f49619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed943200db5a3050595850d8f49619df","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2594b200db5a3050595850d8f4961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Structured Reflective Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The student must submit a structured reflection piece in a form approved by UNSW Law.

The structured reflection piece will focus on the student's Practicum experiences.

Elements of the structured reflection are to be determined by the convenor, but may include:

  • Innovation and technology in legal practice
  • Social values in legal practice
  • Adaptive lawyering
  • Experience-based learning
  • Incidental and informal learning
  • Self-directed learning
  • Formal organisational learning
  • Ways in which the student's capacities for practice were expanded
  • Professional socialisation, and
  • Workplace collaborations together with interpersonal and contextual factors.

As well as the structured reflective portfolio piece for the Practicum, the student must submit their other Loop project reflective work. The Loop project compiles all reflective writing completed throughout the GDLPP.
